title: Review: Noise Exposure – Noise Exposure EP
body: I still remember the first time I experienced _**Unknown Pleasures**_. I was fifteen at the time, and prior to hearing **Joy Division’s** seminal release, the further I’d strayed from conventional manufactured pop was **Fall Out Boy**. Never before had I delved into that submerged level of emotional complexity, not just expressed through **Curtis’s** renowned vocals, but also found amongst the dense layering and mood shattering atmosphere. Suffice to say, **_From Under The Cork Tree_** has not been a regular player since. Whilst Manchester noise-pop duo **Noise Exposure** are still finding their feet, their self-titled debut EP clearly owes much to Curtis & Co. Building a sultry mood through the brooding synths and steady percussion section, combined with the jagged guitar line to forge a rather all enveloping curtain of sound. More modern comparisons could be made to **The Horrors** second album and their slick, refined appearance is vaguely **The Kills**\-esque. The EP is daunting and quietly confident of itself, despite the tracks tellingly similar nature, showing that **Noise Exposure** aren’t too keen to experiment this early in their career. _Your Boat Is Sinking_ and _One Last Hit_ are the EP’s standout moments, both more psychedelic and luxuriously hazy than their predecessors. Whilst there’s an underlying feeling that **Noise Exposure** are yet to truly discover their full potential, I have no doubts that once they will, they’ll be catapulted to a much larger audience.
